conclusion: Looking at the acceleration-time diagram, I need to find the elevator's speed at t=60s by analyzing how the acceleration varies over time and determining its effect on velocity.
The diagram shows acceleration (a) in m/s² plotted against time (t) in seconds. The red-shaded areas in the second image represent the change in velocity.
From t=0 to t=1s: Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s²
From t=1s to t=4s: Constant acceleration of 2 m/s²
From t=4s to t=5s: Acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0
From t=5s to t=55s: Zero acceleration
From t=55s to t=56s: Acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s²
From t=56s to t=59s: Constant acceleration of -2 m/s²
From t=59s to t=60s: Acceleration increases linearly from -2 m/s² to 0

premise: From t=0 to t=1s: Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s²
From t=1s to t=4s: Constant acceleration of 2 m/s²
From t=4s to t=5s: Acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0
From t=5s to t=55s: Zero acceleration
From t=55s to t=56s: Acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s²
From t=56s to t=59s: Constant acceleration of -2 m/s²
